Abstract

This document describes how to use the FLExTrans machine translation system. See section7 for other documentation.

1 Introduction

FLExTrans is a rule-based machine translation system. It was first developed in 2015 (Lockwood 2015). It marries the power of the Apertium (Apertium, 2021) transfer engine with the outstanding lexical model and usability of FLEx.

Figure 1 

FLExTrans is composed basically of two language databases, a list of transfer rules and a series of programs that do the work. The language databases, one for the source language and one for the target language, are in the form of FLEx projects. A FLEx project stores, among other things, a lexicon, grammar settings and a database of texts. The transfer rules are in the form of a text file in XML format. The core programs are the analysis engine, the transfer engine and the synthesis engine. A text in the source language first goes through the analysis process where words are broken down into morphemes. Then the “analyzed” text is transformed into target morphemes and rearranged as necessary in the transfer process. Lastly, the target morphemes are put together into target words in the synthesis process. The end result is a text in the target language.

FLExTrans, as a program, consists of several different modules that are run within the FLExTools[1] program. Upon installation, FLExTools is populated with three collections of modules for common FLExTrans tasks.

2 Getting Started

The basic steps for machine translation with FLExTrans are as follows:

  1. Analyze the text you want to translate in the source FLEx project.
  2. Link lexical senses that are in the source text to senses in the target FLEx project using the Sense Linker Tool
  3. Write transfer rules that convert source words and phrases to target words and phrases.
  4. Run the seven core FLExTrans modules.

Let’s look at each step in more detail.

(It is assumed that you have gone through the installation steps as given on the FLExTrans website and that you have FLExTrans working for the sample projects. It is also assumed that you have two FLEx projects to use as source and target projects for the following steps.)

2.1 Analyze the Source Text

  1. Create a new text in FLEx.
  2. Paste in some text. (Start with a simple text; perhaps just one sentence.)
  3. Analyze this text.
    1. Divide each word into its morphemes.
    2. Accept the analysis of each word.

Word glosses, word categories and free translations are not necessary. A fully analyzed text will look something like (1) below.

(1)

Note: Word gloss and category are hidden as well as free translation.

2.2 Preparatory Steps

  1. Create a new folder for your language pair.
    1. In File Explorer, go to the WorkProjects subfolder of the installation folder (typically Documents\FLExTrans).
    2. Copy the TemplateProject folder and Paste it where it is. You should see a new folder called TemplateProject - Copy
    3. Rename this folder to the name of language pair you will work with.
  2. Enable the sharing option in each of your FLEx projects. This will allow you to keep FLEx projects open while running FLExTrans.
    • From the menu select File > Project Management > FieldWorks Project Properties
    • Click on the Sharing tab.
    • Check the box that says Share project contents with programs on this computer
  3. Add two custom fields to your source FLEx project. This is where link information to the target senses is kept.
    1. In your source FLEx project, go to the Lexicon area
    2. From the menu select Tools > Configure > Custom Fields
    3. Click Add and use the following settings:
      1. Custom Field Name: Target Equivalent[2]
      2. Location: Sense
      3. Type: Single-line Text
      4. Writing Systems(s): First Analysis Writing System
    4. Click Add again and use the following settings for a second custom field:
      1. Custom Field Name: Target Sense Number[2]
      2. Location: Sense
      3. Type: Single-line Text
      4. Writing Systems(s): First Analysis Writing System
    5. Click OK
  4. Start FLExTools. See A.1 for step-by-step instructions. It should look like (2).
    (2)
  5. Click on the button and choose your source database, i.e. FLEx project.
  6. Change the settings for your new project.
    1. Select FLExTrans > Settings from the menu.
    2. You should see the Settings Tool that looks like this:
      (3)
    3. Change these two settings:
      Setting Change to
      Source Text Name The title of the text you want to translate (from the lists of texts in the source FLEx project).
      Target Project The name of your target FLEx project (from the list of FLEx projects).
  7. Setup transfer rule categories and attributes.
    1. Run the Set Up Transfer Rule Categories and Attributes Tool from the Tools collection. You will see a window that looks like (4).
      (4)
      This tool will set up things in your transfer rule file to define your categories and attributes. Find out more about this tool in section 3.6. Find more about transfer rules in section 4.
    2. If you have grammatical templates defined in your FLEx projects, Click the check box for Populate template slots as attributes.
    3. Click OK

2.3 Link Senses

  1. Click on the button which will bring up a list of collections as shown in (5).
    (5)
  2. Click on Tools in the list and you’ll see list of Tools modules:
  3. Click on Sense Linker Tool in the list.
    (6)
  4. Click on the button to run the module. Click OK on the message box that comes up to confirm you want to change FLEx data. You’ll now see the Sense Linker Tool with no links yet established. The window will look something like this:
    (7)
  5. Link each sense. (More details in section3.1)
    1. For blue rows that look good, simply check the check box in the Link It column.
    2. For red rows pick the appropriate target sense in the drop-down list, then double-click in the Target Head Word column for that row.
  6. Click OK

Now you have senses linked from source project to the target. You haven’t created anything in the target project yet, but you have done the preparatory work.

2.4 Write Transfer Rules

In this section, as an exercise, we are going to write a simple rule that removes affixes from words of a certain category. We’ll modify an existing rule to do this.

  1. Navigate to your work project folder.
  2. Open the file transfer_rules.t1x in XMLmind XML Editor. It should look something like (8). This is the transfer rules file that works with the sample projects.
    (8)
  3. Expand the rule element for Verbs and also the output element so that it looks like (9).
    (9)
  4. Pick a category that you are going to process. For this example let’s use noun, abbreviated “n”.
  5. Change the rule comment shown in blue to “Nouns”
  6. We need to change the pattern element so it matches nouns. Change the item element to “c_n”. We will use this to mean: category noun. Category noun gets defined in a later step.
  7. Remove the two literal tag elements by clicking on the word “literal” and pressing the delete key. The rule should now look like (10).
    (10)
  8. Expand the Categories element and the second category element and it should look like (11).
    (11)
  9. Change “c_v” to “c_n” in the category element and “v” to “n” in both tags elements. Now it should look something like (12). Category “c_n” is now defined as the single tag “n” or the tag “n” followed by any other tag, i.e. affixes and the like.
    (12)
  10. Expand the Attributes element and the second attribute element and it should look like (13). Note that we already have a tag for a noun.
    (13)
  11. We are done editing the rule. You can save the file.

In brief what this rule does is set up an action to take place when a word is processed by the Apertium engine that has the “n” tag. (Every word coming from FLEx has the word’s grammatical category in the form of a tag. It’s always the first tag.)

The action that we execute is to strip off any affixes from the word. This is accomplished by outputting the word itself -- the “lem” part and the grammatical category -- anything that matches a tag specified by in the “a_gram_cat” attribute. No other tags (affixes) are explicitly outputted. The target lang. attribute of the clip elements in (10) above is selected so the target word that corresponds to the input source word is outputted.

See sections“A Tutorial on Writing Transfer Rules” and “Transfer Rule How To’s” for more information on transfer rules. The authoritative reference document for transfer rules is found in section 3.5 and appendix 3 of Forcada et al. (2010).

2.5 Run FLExTrans Modules

  1. In FLExTools, click on the button.
  2. Double-click on All Steps in the list and you’ll see (2).
  3. Click on the button to run all the modules. Click OK on the message box that comes up to confirm you want to change FLEx data. You’ll see the modules run and see various bits of output.

You can see the results by opening the target FLEx project. (You may have to do a “refresh” to see the new text.)

3 FLExTrans Tools

3.1 The Sense Linker Tool

The Sense Linker Tool is a tool for linking source senses to target senses. The tool looks through the text specified in the settings and lists every sense that was analyzed in that text in order. Here’s sample screen shot of the Sense Linker Tool:

(14)

3.1.1 Color Coding Key

Here’s a key to the color coding:

Color
White Source sense has been linked to a target sense.
Red Source sense has not been linked to a target sense.
Very Light Blue A target sense has been suggested for this source sense through a partial match of the glosses.
Light Blue A target sense has been suggested for this source sense through an exact match of the glosses.
Green The target sense has been set or changed for this source sense.
Red Text There is a mismatch of grammatical category even though the glosses match.

3.1.2 Linking

For suggested sense links (colored in light blue shades), if you want to link them, simply check the check box in the Link It column. To link a source sense with a target sense where there is no suggestion or to change an existing link, you need to do two things. First, select the target sense that you want to link to in the drop down list of All Target Senses then go to the Target Head Word column for the source sense in question and double-click there. The target sense information should appear with a green background color. You can use the search text box to find the appropriate target sense.

3.1.3 Search the All Target Senses List

Use the Search here field to find a sense. This will find senses in the list by matching the beginning of the headwords in the list. If you want to filter the target sense list to those matching part of a headword or the gloss or the part of speech (using parentheses), click on the Search all fields check box and then type in the Search here box.

3.1.4 Filtering the List

If you only want to see the senses that need to be linked, check the box Show Only Unlinked. If you want to hide proper nouns, which you may not want to bother linking, (especially if the form is the same in both languages) click the box Hide Proper Nouns.

3.1.5 Senses to Link Number

At the bottom left the number of senses left to link is shown. Note that this is not necessarily the number of unchecked boxes, rather the number of unique senses that are remaining to link.

3.1.6 Font Control

Quickly change the font size with the plus and minus buttons next to Zoom. Change all aspects of the font with the Font button.

3.1.7 Rebuild the Bilingual Lexicon

After finishing sense linking, sooner or later you need to rebuild the bilingual lexicon. If the Rebuild the Bilingual Lexicon check box is checked, this will happen automatically when you click OK. If you would like to change whether by default this box is checked or unchecked when you start the Sense Linker Tool, set the corresponding setting in the Settings Tool tool.

3.1.8 Change Source Text

If you want to work on linking senses for a different source text, click the Source Text drop-down box and select the desired text. At this point, the Sense Linker Tool will close and restart.

3.2 The Live Rule Tester Tool

The Live Rule Tester Tool is a tool that allows you to test source words or sentences live against transfer rules. This tool is especially helpful for finding out why transfer rules not are doing what you expect them to do. You can zero in on the problem by selecting just one source word and applying the pertinent transfer rule. In this way you don’t have to run the whole system against the whole text file and all transfer rules. Here’s sample screen shot of the Live Rule Tester Tool:

(15)

3.2.1 Quick Guide

Here’s a quick guide on using the Live Rule Tester Tool.

  1. First you want to choose something from your source text that you want to test. When you first run the tool, the words of the first sentence are shown both in the drop down list at the top and in the peach-colored area. You can check one or more words and when you do the data stream format of the words is shown in the blue-colored area. You can quickly select a whole sentence, by clicking on the Select Sentences tab and clicking on the sentence you want.
  2. Next select which rule or rules you want to run against the words you selected. Check the check boxes in the purple area as appropriate. Check them all with the Select All button. Uncheck them all with the Unselect All button. Move a rule up or down by clicking on it and clicking the up or down arrow buttons.
  3. Now you are ready to test. Click the Transfer button and you will process the selected words. You will see the results in data stream format in the green-colored area.
  4. Check the yellow Information box. It will show which words were matched for the rules that were executed.
  5. Now you are ready to synthesize. Click the Synthesize button and you will synthesize the target text lexical entries in the green-colored area into target words in the salmon-colored area.
  6. Use the Add to Testbed button to add the input words and synthesized result to the "Testbed". This is essentially a database of expected results for a certain inputs. In another part of FLExTrans you can run the Testbed to see if you are still getting the results you expect.

3.2.2 Change Source Text

If you want to work on a different source text, click the Source Text drop-down box and select the desired text. At this point, the Live Rule Tester Tool will close and restart.

3.2.3 Hover to See Bilingual Lexicon Entry

When you are in the Select Words view in the top pane, you can hover over a word to see what the bilingual lexicon entry looks like for that word. As shown in the image above when the word ‘liebe’ was hovered over, the bilingual entry maps ‘lieben’ to ‘älska’. This feature can be very useful when inflection features are present on the target word. These will show in the pop-up as well.

3.2.4 Other Parts of the Tool

By default the transfer rules file, the bilingual lexicon file and the source text are loaded according to the FLExTrans settings. If you want to rebuild the bilingual lexicon, perhaps after changing something in a lexicon, click the Rebuild Bilingual Lexicon button.

You may have noticed that there is a Manual Entry tab for the source text words. You can enter words (technically word-senses) directly in plain text data stream format[13]. This might be useful if you want to test a word-sense that isn’t in a given text.

The Interchunk and Postchunk tabs are for use in testing rules using the advanced Apertium transfer engine.

You can’t edit the transfer rules in the Live Rule Tester Tool and even when you change the order of the rules in the tool that doesn’t change your transfer rules file. Make your changes in the XMLmind XML Editor. You can launch the editor by clicking on the Edit Transfer Rules button. To reload the transfer rules after you have changed them, click on the Refresh Rules button.

The View Bilingual Lexicon and Edit Replacement File buttons will start the XMLmind XML Editor for viewing and editing the respective files.

If you change the target lexicon, click the Refresh Target Lexicon button to reload it so that upon synthesis, FLExTrans uses the changed lexicon.

There is a check box that says Add multiple words to the testbed word by word. Use this when you want to add multiple one-word translations to the testbed in batch. This is useful, for example, if you have a "sentence" that runs through a paradigm. When you click Add to Testbed, FLExTrans will add each individual word and its corresponding synthesis to the testbed in one go. Each pair will be its own test.

3.3 The Settings Tool

The Settings Tool is a tool that helps get FLExTrans configured the way you want it. You launch the Settings Tool by selecting FLExTrans > Settings from the FLExTools menu. Hover over the text box or Browse button to get an explanation of the setting. For file or folder names in the Settings Tool, you can rename the file to be used by simply typing the changes in the pertinent text box.

(16)

3.4 The Source/Target Viewer Tool

The Source/Target Viewer Tool is a tool that allows you to view the Apertium source or target files in an easy-to-read manner. You may not need to examine the Apertium files source_text.txt or target_text.txt very often, but sometimes you may find it useful to see what got extracted from the source FLEx project into source_text.txt or to see what the transfer rules produced after running the RunApertium module in the form of target_text.txt. Run this tool to see the contents of these files. (17) shows what the tool looks like. The actual file contents look like (18).

(17)
(18)

You have the options of changing the font, increasing the zoom level, displaying the text right-to-left or opening a similar view in the default web browser. If you click on the Target button, you will see the contents of target_text.txt.

3.5 Paratext Import and Export Tools

3.5.1 Paratext Import

To import Paratext chapters into the source FLEx project, use the Import Text From Paratext module. Fill out the Paratext project abbreviation in the first box. Note: this must be a project that you are at least an Observer on in Paratext. You cannot import from Paratext resources. Use the Paratext book abbreviation in the second box. You can import multiple chapters.

After importing, you will have a new text in the source FLEx project. It will be named something like the following: John 03-04. Note: if a text with that name already exists, you will get a text with the same name with '- Copy' appended.

Additional options are the following:

  • Include footnotes - include all the text involved with footnotes
  • Include cross references - include all the text involved with cross references, namely \x and \r marked text.
  • Make a new text the active text - the newly created text will be configured to be the active source text in FLExTrans. This means FLExTrans modules will use it.
  • Use full English book name for title - e.g. JHN will change to John.
(19)

3.5.2 Paratext Export

To export chapters to Paratext from the active text, use the Export Text From Paratext module. This tool is designed to work well with a text that you have previously imported with the Import Text From Paratext module. In other words, the export tool expects the active source text to be in the form John 03-04 or JHN 03-04. Use the Settings Tool tool if you need to change the active source text. The tool will find the book and chapters in the given Paratext project and replace the text that was there with the text created by FLExTrans.[3] Note: the Paratext project must be a project that you are at least a Translator on. Also, the Paratext book must already exist.

Normally this module should be run after the Extract Target Lexicon module.

(20)

3.6 The Set Up Transfer Rule Categories and Attributes Tool

The Set Up Transfer Rule Grammatical Categories Tool will populate categories and attributes in your transfer rule file. Use this tool when you are first setting up your transfer rules. You are given a choice for populating attributes as shown in (21). Source categories & the a_gram_cat attribute are always processed.

(21)

3.6.1 Source Categories

This tool finds all the grammatical categories in the source FLEx project and creates corresponding categories under the Categories element in the transfer rule file. Source categories will always be created with this tool, unless an existing category of the same name is found.

3.6.2 a_gram_cat Attribute

This tool that will put the necessary attribute values for grammatical categories into your transfer rules file. Every transfer rule will likely need to reference the grammatical category of a word either in the source or target language. The initial transfer rules file that comes with FLExTrans has just a few sample grammatical categories. This tool will take the categories that are in the source and target FLEx projects and insert them as tags under the specific attribute called a_gram_cat in the transfer rules file. The list of grammatical categories will be a complete list of all the unique categories in both projects.

(22) shows what the a_gram_cat attribute might look like after running this tool.

(22)

3.6.3 Inflection Features

Click the appropriate check box as shown in (21) to populate attributes in your transfer rules that correspond to the inflection features in both of your FLEx projects. Click the overwrite check box to change existing attributes in your transfer rule file with the inflection features from the FLEx projects.

3.6.4 Inflection Classes

Click the appropriate check box as shown in (21) to populate attributes in your transfer rules that correspond to the inflection classes in both of your FLEx projects. Click the overwrite check box to change existing attributes in your transfer rule file with the inflection classes from the FLEx projects.

3.6.5 Template Slots

Click the appropriate check box as shown in (21) to populate attributes in your transfer rules that correspond to template slots in both of your FLEx projects. Click the overwrite check box to change existing attributes in your transfer rule file with the template slots from the FLEx projects.

4 A Tutorial on Writing Transfer Rules[4]

Writing transfer rules is not as tricky as it might seem. People generally understand the basic concepts, but they sometimes struggle with the formalism. Maybe one of the reasons people struggle is that the formalism mixes declarative and procedural statements. This tutorial should help you get used to writing transfer rules.

4.1 Overview

Here’s a brief overview:

4.1.1 Some Formalities

Before starting, it is important to get an idea of what we can’t do, before explaining what we can.

  • There are no recursive rules. Rules match fixed-length patterns. There is no optionality at the level of words. There is no way of saying one or more, it’s just one.
  • Rules contain both declarative parts and procedural parts. You can’t just expect to say what you want or how you want to do it. You need to do both -- but in different places (but it’s quite intuitive).
  • Patterns match only on the source side, not on the target side.
  • The transfer process has no access to the information in the target language dictionary. This means that if the transfer needs some information about the available forms of a particular word, e.g. if it is only singular, or only plural, then this information needs to go in the bilingual dictionary.

4.1.2 Approaching the Process of Writing Transfer Rules

Think bottom up, not top down. Start with a question like “What is the simplest and best equivalent for dative in a language which does not have dative?” not “How can I change SOV order to SVO order?”

4.1.3 Lexical Transfer and Structural Transfer

We don’t want to confuse the roles of lexical transfer and structural transfer. There is a grey area between the two, but there are also big parts that don’t overlap.

  • Lexical transfer (the bilingual.dix file -- produced by the Sense Linker Tool and the Extract Bilingual Lexicon module)
    • Nearly always gives translations between words, not tags.
    • Can add or change tags, on a per-sense basis.
    • Doesn’t do reordering.
    • Can be used to give a head’s up to the structural transfer to draw attention to missing features, or features that cannot be decided on a no-context basis.
  • Structural transfer (the transfer_rules.t1x file -- edited with XMLmind XML Editor)
    • Rarely gives translations between single words.
    • Often adds or changes tags on a per-category (groups of words) basis.
    • Can change the order of words.

A rule-of-thumb is, if the rule applies to all words in a category, it probably wants to be treated in the structural transfer; if it applies to just part of those words, then maybe it needs to be dealt with in the lexical transfer.

Lexical transfer for a three word text looks like (23). In other words, the bilingual dictionary maps a source word to target word. In FLExTrans you don’t normally need to examine the bilingual dictionary, but conceptually it looks like this. Open the bilingual.dix in the XML Mind editor for the details.

(23)
slword1.1 somecat -> tlword1.1 somecat
slword12.1 somecat blah -> tlword31.2 somecat foo
slword33.1 somecat blah -> tlword21.1 somecat GD

The output of the structural transfer would look like (24).

(24)
tlword1.1 somecat tlword31.2 somecat foo tlword21.1 somecat GD

When you are in the structural transfer stage, you have access to both the source and target sides.

4.1.3.1 How Lexical Transfer is Processed

This isn’t critical information that you have to know, but gives insight into what’s going on. Feel free to skip this section.

Given an input lexical unit shown in (25):

(25)
slword1.1 cat1 aff2 aff3

If we have the following in the bilingual dictionary:

(26)

Which gives the following mapping in terms of lexical units:

(27)
slword1.1 cat1 aff2 -> tlword1.1 cat1

We will get this target-language output from the lexical-transfer module:

(28)
tlword1.1 cat1 aff3

Note that the target-language lexical form, as defined in the bilingual dictionary entry in (26), is produced by replacing two tags on the source side (i.e. cat1 aff2) with one tag on the target side (i.e. cat1).

Important: any source language tags not matched in the bilingual dictionary entry are copied into the output on the target language side. In our example, aff3 in (25) gets copied to the final output in (28).

4.1.4 Some Preliminaries

The transfer rule file is written in an XML format and in FLExTrans it is named transfer_rules.t1x[5]. We could do all the editing of the transfer rules in a text editor, but by using the structured editor XMLmind XML Editor we not only get a graphical user interface, but also verification that the rule file we are writing is valid. In fact the XMLmind XML Editor and the add-ons for FLExTrans make it hard to write an invalid rule file.

4.1.5 Overview of a Transfer File

It’s hard to give a step-by-step overview of what a transfer file looks like because there is quite a lot of obligatory parts that need to go into even the most basic file. But, it’s important to get a general view before we go into the details. Here is an example in which I’m deliberately not going to use linguistic names for the different parts to try and avoid assumptions.

(29)

You should see this same thing when you open the file transfer_rules.t1x (FLExTrans Documentation\Transfer Rules Tutorial folder) in the XMLmind XML Editor. (Expand all the elements.)

The transfer file is divided into two main parts: a declaration section and a rules section. The rules section uses information from the declaration section. In fact, every kind of reference you make in the rules section, you have to declare in the declaration section. The rules section is clearly denoted by the element Rules. All of the elements above Rules are part of the declaration section. In (29) a minimal amount of declarations are shown, namely the Categories, Attributes, and Variables elements. (The elements Lists and Macros are not shown.)

Rules have two main parts: the pattern definition and the actions to be carried out.

The pattern element is what determines if Apertium runs the rule or not. If the input word or words match the pattern, Apertium will run the rule. The thing that goes in the item sub-element of the pattern element is a list of one or more categories (from the declaration section) you want to match.

The action element contains the steps you want to perform in the rule, generally ending with an output element where you output lexical units into the data stream. Note how declared attributes are used in the action element. Categories and attributes are discussed more below.

4.1.6 How Rules are Applied

Rules are applied when a pattern is matched in the source language input data stream. Which patterns are matched in which order goes like this: the longest patterns are attempted first and then successive shorter patterns are attempted. When there is more than one pattern of the same length, the pattern that comes first in the file is attempted first followed by the rest in order.

Patterns do not overlap. Once a pattern is matched, the matched words are processed and not considered again for any other patterns. In other words, the source language words are processed sequentially in chunks. Cf. “How does pattern matching work?”.

4.2 Practical Example

(30)
Input: Otišla si tiho i bez pozdrava
Output: You left quietly and without a word

Let’s do an exercise where the goal is to turn a sentence in Croatian into English. The input and desired output is shown in (30).

4.2.1 Getting Set Up

  1. There are two FLEx projects already set up that we are going to use. You will find them in the FLExTrans Documentation\Transfer Rules Tutorial folder. They are called Croatian-FLExTrans-Sample ... .fwbackup and English-FLExTrans-Sample ... .fwbackup. Double-click on them one by one to restore them into FLEx.
  2. In the same folder, you'll find a folder named Croatian-English. Copy the folder and navigate to the FLExTrans\WorkProjects folder and Paste it there.
  3. Start FLExTools. See A.1 for step-by-step instructions.
  4. Verify that the status bar shows the current collection is set to All Steps.

4.2.2 Lexical Transfer

For the purposes of this example, we are going to use some “pre-prepared” data. We have a Croatian text that is already analyzed and we have small Croatian and English lexicons with all of the entries and senses that we need.

Let’s see what our input and output looks like initially if we run the system. Our input of course, according to (30) is: Otišla si tiho i bez pozdrava.

  1. Go to the FLExTools app.
  2. Click the Database button that currently says German-FLExTrans-Sample, select Croatian-FLExTrans-Sample and type the Enter key.
  3. Click the Run All button to run all the FLExTrans modules.
  4. Open the English-FLExTrans-Sample FLEx project.
  5. In the Texts and Words view, refresh the screen and click on the text titled “Left Behind”.

You should see:

(31)
Leavepfvptcp f sg beprssg2 quietly and without wordgen sg

Clearly we have some work to do, but at least three words look good. (31) is what we get using straight lexical transfer. In other words, English word-senses are substituted for Croatian word-senses. The sample transfer rule we are using (shown in (29)) is having no influence during the transfer process.

Let’s look at the input and output in data stream format.

(32)
Input:[6] Otići1.1 v pfv ptcp_f_sg biti1.1 cop prs sg 2 tiho1.1 adv i1.1 coordconn bez1.1 prep pozdrav1.1 n gen_sg
Output:[7] Leave1.1 v pfv ptcp_f_sg be1.1 cop prs sg 2 quietly1.1 adv and1.1 coordconn without1.1 prep word1.1 n gen_sg

4.2.3 Thinking it Through

Let’s think about what changes we need to make in order to convert the output shown in (32) into an adequate form for target language synthesis. NB: If we want to change information, it’s a procedure; if we want to output information or not output information, it’s a declaration.

4.2.3.1 Procedures

  1. If the source language grammatical category tag is ptcp_f_sg, change the target language tag to pst[8]

4.2.3.2 Declarations

  1. Output a subject pronoun which takes its person and number information from the auxiliary verb.
  2. Output the main verb with information on category and tense (but not aspect).
  3. Do not output the auxiliary verb biti, “be”.
  4. Output nouns with their grammatical category (but not number or case).

4.2.3.3 Work Order

So, what order do we do these in? Well it doesn’t really matter. An experienced FLExTrans linguist would probably do it in two steps, but for pedagogical purposes, we’re going to split it up into five steps:

  • First, we’re going to write a rule which matches the participle and auxiliary construction and outputs only the main verb (declarations: 2 & 3).
    • Define the categories of “ptcp_f_sg” and “biti”.
  • Second, we’re going to edit that rule to change the source language tag from ptcp_f_sg to pst (procedure: 1).
    • Define the attribute of “tense”.
  • Third, we’re going to edit the same rule to not output aspect (declaration: 2).
    • Define the attribute for grammatical category and add the tag for “verb”.
  • Fourth, we’re going to edit the same rule to output a subject pronoun before the verb (declaration: 1).
    • Define the attributes of “person” and “number”.
  • Fifth, we’re going to write a new rule which matches the noun construction and output only the grammatical category (declaration: 4)
    • Define the category of “noun”.
    • Add the tag for nouns to the grammatical category attribute.

4.2.3.4 Cheat Sheet

Here is what the input and output data stream of each of the above steps will look like:

(33)
Step Input Output
1 Otići1.1 v pfv ptcp_f_sg biti1.1 cop prs sg 2 Leave1.1 v pfv ptcp_f_sg
2 Otići1.1 v pfv ptcp_f_sg biti1.1 cop prs sg 2 Leave1.1 v pfv pst
3 Otići1.1 v pfv ptcp_f_sg biti1.1 cop prs sg 2 Leave1.1 v pst
4 Otići1.1 v pfv ptcp_f_sg biti1.1 cop prs sg 2 Propers1.1 pro nom 2 sg leave1.1 v pst
5 pozdrav1.1 n gen_sg word1.1 n

4.2.4 Implementation

Let’s see what data stream output we get for the first two words right now. To do this we will use the Live Rule Tester Tool which is a great tool for applying a single rule to one or more words and checking the result. See section3.2.

  1. Close the English-FLExTrans-Sample FLEx project.
  2. Bring up the FLExTools app.
  3. Click the Collections button.
  4. Double-click on the Tools collection.
  5. Select the Live Rule Tester Tool module.
  6. Click on the Run button.
  7. Check the first two Croatian words.
  8. Click on the Transfer button.

Your Live Rule Tester Tool should look like this:

(34)

In the blue box we have the input data stream for the first two (checked) Croatian words:

(35)
Otići1.1 v pfv ptcp_f_sg biti1.1 cop prs sg 2

This matches what we have in the cheat sheet in (33).

In the green box we have the output data stream after the sample rule is applied.

(36)
Leave1.1 v pfv ptcp_f_sg be1.1 cop prs sg 2

Since we haven’t done anything, it doesn’t yet match our output goal for step one in the cheat sheet.

4.2.4.1 Step 1

  1. Define the categories we need in transfer_rules.t1x. Replace the dummy Categories element with:

    (37)

    You may be wondering how you get a new category element inserted. It is straightforward:

    1. Click on the word “category”. The whole element becomes outlined in a red rectangle.
    2. Now either right-click and choose Insert After... or click on the button (upper right side) or press Ctrl-J.
    3. At this point a list of elements to insert shows up in the upper right pane as shown in (38).
      (38)
    4. Choose in this case def-cat(category) since we only need one tags element. (By the way, this insert procedure will present only valid elements that can be inserted at this point in the rules file.)

    Why do we need .* in the tags elements? This is because of how the matching system for categories works. In the middle of tag sequences, a * is counted as a single tag. At the end, it is counted as any sequence of tags. So, what we have is v followed by any tag, followed by ptcp_f_sg.

    Note: we are using the convention of starting all categories with “c_”.

  2. Edit the example rule and replace the pattern as shown. Also change the rule comment to “Past Construction”.
    (39)

    Trick: Click in the pink area of the item element and press F11. You will get a list of possible categories that can be used in this element. The list looks like (40).

    (40)

    By using this pattern we will detect a participle followed by the auxiliary. Once detected, the rule will run.

    Notice that the example rule as written outputs only the first among two lexical units as seen in (41) (“item: 1” means the first item or word). We are not outputting the 2nd word. The result is that our biti1.1 word will disappear.

    (41)
  3. Test it in the Live Rule Tester Tool.
    1. Save the rule file.
    2. Bring up the Live Rule Tester Tool.
    3. Click the Refresh Rules button to reload the modified rule file.
    4. Click on the Transfer button. (This time you will notice some text in the yellow information box. This shows which rules matched which input words.)

    The result is:

    (42)
    Leave1.1 v pfv ptcp_f_sg

    Great!

4.2.4.2 Step 2

  1. Replace the dummy attribute element with an attribute that gives possible values of the tense feature.

    So, now that we’ve gotten rid of the verb “be”, we want to change the tag for tense from ptcp_f_sg to pst. This will involve using a procedure statement, explicitly telling the transfer what we want to change. But before that, we need to define which possible values our feature can take. We do this with the attribute element. Let’s call it “a_tense”. Note we are using the convention of starting all attributes with “a_”.

    Add the following under the Attributes element:
    (43)
  2. Write a statement which changes the tense on the target language. This statement should go immediately after the action element and before the output element. Make sure you select the target lang. property.
    (44)
    Trick: Click in the brown area of the part property and press F11. You will get a list of possible attributes that can be used in this element. The list looks like (45).
    (45)
    (Note: the statement in (44) will always change the target language tag to pst, even if the input is not ptcp_f_sg. This is good enough for our current example, but for a description of how conditional logic works, see Section6.2.7.

  3. Now test it in the Live Rule Tester Tool. (Don’t forget to refresh the rules first!)

    The result is:

    (46)
    Leave1.1 v pfv pst

    Excellent!

4.2.4.3 Step 3

So far we have been outputting the whole target language lexical unit, as seen in (48) below.

An important thing to know about lexical transfer is that any source language tags not matched in the bilingual dictionary are copied into the output on the target language side. In our case, pfv pst are the tags that get copied from source to target because, in the bilingual dictionary (bilingual.dix), otići1.1 v maps to leave1.1 v. All we need is the pst tag; we don’t need the pfv tag, so we need to declare that it should not be outputted.

  1. Define the features that we want to output.

    We have already defined the attribute “tense”: the only remaining tag we need to output is the grammatical category, i.e. v meaning verb. So, make a new attribute element for grammatical category.[9]
    (47)
  2. Declare which attributes we want to output.

    So, now that we’ve got our two attributes defined, let’s change our output statement: (You will have to open the output element with the plus sign.)

    Where we previously had:
    (48)
    Replace it with:
    (49)
    The last two attributes we know, as we’ve just added them. The “lem” attribute is a predefined feature which corresponds to lemma, i.e. the part before the tags. In this example it would be leave1.1. There are other predefined features, but if you remember this one and “whole” which corresponds to the whole lexical unit, you have the main ones.

  3. Now test it in the Live Rule Tester Tool. (Don’t forget to refresh the rules first!)

    The result is:

    (50)
    Leave1.1 v pst

    Woo! What just happened was that we magically deleted the unwanted pfv tag by not specifying that we wanted it. Tag deletion is thus not stated as tag deletion (tag → 0), but by not declaring it.

    Now we should have a lexical form for “leave” which we can synthesize. Let’s give it a go. Click the Synthesize button.

    In the red box you should see:

    (51)
    Left

    And if you click on the rest of the check boxes to select all of the Croatian words and click the Transfer and Synthesize buttons again you should see:

    (52)
    Left quietly and without wordgen sg

    This looks a lot better than our initial results in (31). The word Left is now there correctly. It’s beyond the scope of this exercise to explain in detail how the synthesis works in this case, but the tag pst matches the feature pst on the variant form of the verb leave. See section 6.3.3 for more details.

    We’re getting there, now let’s move on to the next step.

4.2.4.4 Step 4

To recap, the input we’ve been working with is:

(53)
Otići1.1 v pfv ptcp_f_sg biti1.1 cop prs sg 2

And our current output is:

(54)
Leave1.1 v pst

What we now need to do is take the information from the (not outputted) verb biti “be” and use it to output a personal pronoun before the verb. Remember that when we do not output something we are not deleting it. It is still there in the input, we are just choosing not to put it in the output.

The pronoun that we want to output looks like (55). If we get it in this form, it will synthesize into the word you.

(55)
propers1.1 pro nom 2 sg

Important: We need to remember to output the 1.1 after the word and not just propers. Even though in the target FLEx project the lexeme form is propers, FLExTrans automatically adds the homograph number (1 because it’s the first and only homograph) and the sense number (1 because it’s the first sense). If we mistakenly use propers instead of propers1.1, the word won’t synthesize because FLExTrans won’t find propers in its internal dictionary. This use of x.x after the word helps FLExTrans identify each unique sense in the dictionary.

  1. Output a skeleton pronoun.

    So, we need to take the person and number information from the verb “be”, and the rest we need to just declare to be outputted. Let’s start with outputting the string propers1.1 pro nom; we won’t worry about the 2 sg tags yet.

  2. Insert a new lexical unit before our current lexical unit element and make it look like (56).

    You can do an Insert Before... and choose lu(lexical_unit_lit-string) then click on the literal string, do an Insert After... and choose lit-tag(literal_tag). The blank space element comes after and is indented at the same level as lexical unit.

    (56)
    The lexical unit statement means we are outputting a word[10]. The literal string element outputs the given string of characters, and the literal tag element outputs a tag sequence[11]. Multiple tags are separated by a period, so in this case we are outputting two tags: pro and nom. The blank space element outputs a single space character.

  3. Define features for person and number.

    The next step is to declare the features from the verb “be” to output. To do this we need to again define some attributes and their possible values. Add this:
    (57)
  4. We then go back to our skeleton pronoun and add the missing features. So that it looks like (58).

    Click on the literal tag element and Insert After... and choose clip(clip_source_language). Do this twice.

    (58)
    Note that we are “clipping” (copying a part of a string which matches a pattern) from position 2, i.e. the verb “be”. To be clearer, the first clip statement in (58) makes a copy of the part of the lexical unit in position 2, on the source language side, which matches one of the patterns defined in the attribute element “a_pers” (which can be either 1, 2 or 3). If we look at the lexical transfer output which is internally coming from the bilingual dictionary for position 2, this will become clearer:

    (59)
    biti1.1 cop prs sg 2 -> be1.1 cop prs sg 2
    |                ||   |              |
    |           person|   |              |
    |_________________|   |______________|
      source language      target language
    If we tried to clip from position 1 (Otići1.1 v pfv ptcp_f_sg), we would get no result for the person attribute because the verb in position 1 does not contain any tags which match the tags in the definition for person.

  5. Now test it in the Live Rule Tester Tool. (Go back to having just Otišla and si checked.)

    The result is:

    (60)
    propers1.1 pro nom 2 sg Leave1.1 v pst

    Select all the Croatian words, do Transfer and Synthesize and see what our English sentence looks like.

    Now we get:

    (61)
    you Left quietly and without wordgen sg

    We get the second person singular pronoun that we wanted, but this is not totally satisfying because you should be capitalized and Left should not be. Let’s fix that.

    1. We want to be careful, because we don’t want you capitalized in all circumstances. For example, if the Croatian past tense clause is embedded in another phrase, the first word may not be capitalized. What we can do is check what the capitalization of the verb is and apply that same capitalization to the pronoun. Make your lexical unit element look like (62):
      (62)
      Notice how the literal string element is indented under the get case from element. This means that it is a child element of the get case from element. To accomplish this, XMLmind XML Editor has a way to wrap an element around another element. This is what you do.
      1. Click on the words “literal string”. The whole element becomes outlined in a red rectangle.
      2. Either right-click and choose Convert [wrap]... or click on the button (upper right side) or press Ctrl-Shift-T.
      3. At this point a list of elements to insert shows up in the upper right pane. Choose get-case-from.
      4. Now set the item property to 1 and we will be getting the capitalization from the first word.

    2. Now we need to make the second lexical unit come out with the first letter in lower case. We could use the modify-case element, but we would have to add a new statement above the output element. Instead we can just use the same method as above to get the case from the second word. This time wrap the get case from element around the clip element that copies the lemma. This is shown below:
      (63)
      Trick: Click on the word "clip" and type Ctrl-a. This will execute the last command you did in the XMLmind XML Editor again (namely wrap an element with the get case from element.)

    Transfer and Synthesize again.

    Now we get:

    (64)
    You left quietly and without wordgen sg

    Looking good!

4.2.4.5 Step 5

The last remaining thing to do is to not output the genitive or singular tags on the noun. We’re going to have to make a whole new rule to match nouns.

  1. Define a category for nouns.
    (65)
  2. Make a new rule which matches nouns as defined by the previous category. To start with, we’ll just output the whole lexical unit.
    (66)
  3. Add nouns to the grammatical category attribute element. Now it looks like this:
    (67)
  4. Adjust the rule to output only the lemma and grammatical category.
    (68)

    Now test it in the Live Rule Tester Tool, but this time check only the Croatian word pozdrava. Note: if you refresh the rules, the new Nouns rule will not automatically get checked in the rule list. Check the box for the new rule before testing it.

    Starting with:

    (69)
    pozdrav1.1 n gen_sg

    The result is:

    (70)
    word1.1 n

    And if we Synthesize we get:

    (71)
    word

    Close the Live Rule Tester Tool and run the modules in the All Steps to see what our English sentence looks like.

    Now we get:

    (72)
    You left quietly and without word

    Success!

4.2.4.6 Step 6

Step 6 is left as an exercise for the reader. Change the noun rule to output an indefinite article before the noun. You can do this by following the instructions for adding the pronoun, see “Step 4”. The string you need to output is a1.1 indf.

You can find the solution transfer file called solution.t1x in the FLExTrans\WorkProjects folder.

You may think this was a lot of work to translate one sentence from Croatian to English, but consider the fact that now every Croatian past tense construction that occurs in a text will correctly be translated to English and every indefinite noun will also be handled.

5 The FLExTrans Testbed

The FLExTrans Testbed is a system designed to help you maintain the quality of your translations. It not uncommon, as you add new transfer rules to the system or change the lexicons, you mess up the results you were getting before. To help prevent this, it is very helpful to have a database of expected results for a certain inputs. This is called a testbed. After making significant changes to your translation system, you can re-run the testbed to make sure you are still getting the results you expect for words or sentences that you earlier deemed correct.

5.1 Workflow with the Testbed

This is the way you normally work with the testbed:

  1. Make a change to the system, e.g. add a new rule or other changes.
  2. Use the Live Rule Tester Tool to verify you are getting the results you expect.
  3. Click the Add to Testbed button to add one or more tests that prove source words are correctly translating to the target.
  4. Now run the testbed to verify that all your previous tests still give the expected result.
    1. Open the Run Testbed collection.
    2. Click the Run All button to run all the modules.
    3. Review the Testbed Log which will open at the end and show you the results of running the testbed.
  5. Make any adjustments as needed. Repeat. If you need to edit the testbed, open the file testbed.xml which is in the project folder in the XMLmind XML Editor.

5.2 Testbed Tools

FLExTrans has a collection of tools to help you maintain the testbed, run the testbed and see the results.

5.2.1 Testbed Log Viewer

This module you will find in both the Tools and Run Testbed collections. Simply run the module and you will see a log of all the times the testbed has been run with a summary of the results. The most recently run test opens and lets you see the details for each test. Hover over the Source Lexical Units of a test to see some pop-up text of which FLEx source text the words came from. If the rule was invalid, the pop-up text will also tell you why FLExTrans found the test invalid.

(73)

5.2.2 Start Testbed

This module you will find at the top of the Run Testbed collection. It initializes a test run and dumps all of the source lexical units in the testbed into the source_text.txt file.

5.2.3 End Testbed

This module you will find as the next to last module in the Run Testbed collection. It takes the results of running the transfer and synthesis processes (the source_text.txt file) and adds the tests run and whether they passed or not to the testbed log.

5.2.4 Live Rule Tester Tool

The Live Rule Tester Tool is a good place to add new tests to the testbed. See “The Live Rule Tester Tool” for more details.

5.2.5 Testbed Editing

It’s easiest to add new tests to the testbed while in the Live Rule Tester Tool. If you need to edit or delete a test, edit the file testbed.xml in the project folder with the XMLmind XML Editor.

6 FLExTrans How To’s

6.1 Complete Process for Translating One Verse (video)

6.2 Transfer Rule How To’s

6.2.1 How do I use the category element in the transfer rules?

Lexical categories are used to group words together. The grouping can be very broad such as verbs or very specific such as pronouns with feminine suffixes. The categories are used in the pattern matching system of transfer rules.

(74)

(74) is an example of a lexical category for indefinite nominals. The period indicates where a new tag begins. The asterisk is a wildcard indicator. It means that anything can fill that position. An asterisk at the end of the item matches one or more final tags. For example, if I have the lexical unit book1.1 n f sg, it could be precisely matched by a tags element containing n.f.sg. More generally we could match book with the tags element containing n.f.*. This would refer to all words that have the grammatical category n followed by the tag f followed by anything else, i.e. feminine nouns. (74) defines the set of all indefinite nouns — words that have the grammatical category n or n-irreg followed by ind and optionally something else afterward. Note that n.ind and n.ind.* are both necessary because n.ind.* would require some affix after ind and not match an indefinite noun like car1.1 n ind that has no additional suffixes..

You can use the lemma element to identify a specific word-sense. (75) shows how the category dem_this can be defined as a word that has a grammatical category of dem and lemma this1.1 (in FLEx: headword this1 , sense 1). This might be useful when you want to match phrases containing the word this.

(75)

6.2.2 How do I use the attribute element in the transfer rules?

Attributes are defined in the rule file in order to identify possible values for word characteristics. An example is shown in (76).

(76)

Certain words may have affixes that indicate grammatical number. (76) defines the possible values for the number attribute as being sg (singular) or pl (plural). Like lexical categories, these refer to tags in the data stream. Attributes are used within rules to get or set values.

6.2.3 How does pattern matching work?

The Apertium transfer engine searches for patterns in your source text. The patterns it searches for are those defined for each rule you have. Some patterns may be one word, some patterns may be multiple words. The transfer engine tries to match the longest patterns first and then progressively goes to shorter and shorter patterns. This means a five-word pattern would be used before a three-word pattern (assuming a set of words would match both patterns.) When there are multiple patterns of the same length, the first one listed gets precedence. This means in some cases the order of your rules will be important.

The transfer engine searches for matches in your words in sequential order starting with the first word. It will never find a match at some point in a text and then go back earlier in the text.

Another important concept is that the transfer engine processes words just once for whatever pattern is matched. After they are processed, the words are not examined again for any other matches. In other words, patterns cannot apply in an overlapping manner. For example, if you have a rule that matches determiner-noun and another one that matches noun-adjective, when a sentence of the form determiner-noun-adjective is processed. The engine uses the rule that is listed first and then discards the three words and continues on to other words. The second rule does not get applied. Another way to describe it is to say that the engine processes words in distinct chunks.

If the Apertium transfer engine finds a match, it runs the action part of your rule. If the engine finds no match for a word, it does default translation of it according to what is in the bilingual dictionary. Cf. “How Rules are Applied”.

6.2.4 How do I delete a word from the target output? (How do I prevent a source word from being transferred to the target text?)

The short answer is don’t output it. In other words, don’t declare that it should be outputted into the target data stream.

When you match two or more words in the pattern section of a transfer rule, you can choose to only list some of the words in the output section. This is exactly what we did in “Step 1” of the tutorial. In (41) we only declared that the word in position 1 should be outputted.

6.2.5 How do I insert a word into the target output?

Naturally to add something to the target output, we need to add something to the output part of our transfer rule. And what goes in output part the of our transfer rule? Lexical units. We need to insert a lexical unit block under the output element of our transfer rule. The bare minimum we need for a lexical unit is the word-sense and the grammatical category. If we are manually outputting a word-sense, we need to use a literal string element and the text needs to be of the form word1.2. Where 1 would be the homograph number (if there isn’t one in FLEx, use 1) and 2 would be the sense number. In this case the second sense of the word. (77) shows how it might look.

(77)

Of course you can output affixes or clitics as well. These would be additional literal string elements. Remember the first literal tag is the grammatical category, all subsequent tags are affixes and the like. If you have a valid word-sense and its corresponding grammatical category, FLExTrans will look up this word-sense in the target FLEx lexicon and use it in the final synthesis process.

If you have other lexical units that you will be outputting, remember to put a blank space element so that you get a space between your words. This is shown in (56). “Step 4” of the transfer rules tutorial shows an example of inserting a word into the target output.

6.2.6 How do I delete an affix?

There are two methods for deleting an affix. You can either set the value for that affix (attribute) to blank or you can not declare that the affix (attribute) gets outputted.

  1. Method 1. Use the let element to set an attribute’s value to blank. See (78).
    (78)
    Here we are overriding whatever is in the tense attribute (a_tense) with a blank string. Whenever the tense affix gets outputted, it will be outputted as nothing. As an example, in (79) the whole word is outputted with all its attributes.
    (79)
  2. Method 2. In the Output element, explicitly declare each attribute of the word that you want to output. Don’t include the attribute that needs to be deleted.
    (80)
    In (80) you can see that the lemma is outputted and then the grammatical category and then two attribute. The disadvantage of this method is that you have to explicitly declare every possible attribute that could occur. Where as in (79) in Method 1, you just have to output the whole word.

6.2.7 How do I use conditional logic in a transfer rule? (How do I say if this ... then that?) (video)

In the transfer rules you have the ability to use conditional logic. Please watch this video for an explanation. Also see examples of conditional logic in the rule: Sample logic to copy and paste.

6.2.8 How do I use a macro? (How can I repeat rule statements in multiple places?) (video)

In the transfer rules you have the ability to modularize your rules by putting repeated logic into a macro. Please watch this video for an explanation.

6.2.9 How do I handle noun agreement? (How do I get a target word or words to agree with a noun?) (video)

One main strategy for getting words to agree with a noun, is to make sure features are assigned to the noun and then in the transfer rules make the needed adjustment to the words you output depending on what the feature values (or class values) are.

To see how to do this in a sample language pair, please watch video 1 and video 2.

If you would like to try creating the rules along with the video, please follow the instructions in the file: Readme.txt in the Doc\Agreement folder. See the file transfer_rules - solution.t1x which shows the form of the rules shown in the video.

6.2.10 How do I use the Sample logic that's in the transfer rules file?

Each sample logic block starts with a comment shown in yellow. Read through each of the most outdented comments to see what kind of logic matches your need. When you find one, click on the first black word under the comment. That will select the block (outlined in red). Now you can copy that block and put it into your own rule.

6.3 Other How To’s

6.3.1 How do I view the bilingual lexicon?

You can view the bilingual lexicon by double-clicking on the file bilingual.dix in the Output folder. An example portion of a bilingual lexicon is shown in (81).

(81)

6.3.2 I have a source word that maps to two different target words depending on the inflection of the source word. How do I handle that?

You can handle this by using the replace.dix file to add additional mappings to the bilingual lexicon. This file is your project folder.

The bilingual lexicon is a mapping of source word-senses to target word-senses. There are no inflectional affixes present in the bilingual lexicon. That's the way FLExTrans builds it. In theory, though, there could be inflectional features or classes present. An example portion of a bilingual lexicon is shown in (82). You can view the bilingual lexicon by double-clicking on the file bilingual.dix in the Output folder. Both the replace.dix and bilingual.dix files are XML files and will load automatically in XMLmind XML Editor.

(82)

In order to have a word map differently than what is in the bilingual lexicon, you need to add a line to the replacement file. If you double-click on replace.dix in the project folder, you will see something like (83).

(83)

The replacement file has two main sections, one for replacing default bilingual entries with ones of your choice and one section for appending new entries to the bilingual lexicon. We are interested in doing the latter. Note, we can’t edit the bilingual dictionary file directly because it gets generated automatically by FLExTrans. After FLExTrans generates it, FLExTrans replaces and appends entries from the replacement file.

Let’s say that we want to map the past tense of the entry for lieben shown in (82) to a different Swedish word, we change the replacement file to something like (84).

(84)

Let’s look closer at the last line. The left element has lieben1.1 and the “symbol” v just like the bilingual file, but it also has a new symbol pst. This is the gloss for the past suffix in German. By adding this suffix, we are telling FLExTrans that we are mapping the past inflection of lieben1.1 to something else. The new Swedish word is listed for the right element. Note that we also had to add a new symbol definition, pst so that FLExTrans knows the symbol is. Any symbols you use in a section of the replacement file, have to be defined under the Symbols element.

6.3.3 How do I handle inflectional variants in the target language? (video)

To learn how FLExTrans can handle these kind of variants, please watch this video.

The key thing in the techniques explained in the videos is to get inflectional features assigned to Irregularly Inflected Form variants that match exactly the suffixes that would normally be used.

If you would like to try doing the same thing while watching the video, please follow the instructions in the file: Readme.txt in the Doc\Irregular Form folder.

6.3.4 How do I handle inflectional variants in the source language? (video)

To learn how FLExTrans can handle these kind of variants, please watch this video.

The key thing in the techniques explained in the videos is to get inflectional features assigned to Irregularly Inflected Form variants that match exactly the suffixes that would normally be used.

If you would like to try doing the same thing while watching the video, please follow the instructions in the file: Readme.txt in the Doc\Irregular Form folder. Note: be sure to set the Source Text Name property in the FLExTrans settings to “Text2”.

6.3.5 How do I run a Synthesis Self-Test?

To test whether a Target project is ready for Synthesis (without interacting with a source project), do the following:

  1. In FLEx, in your Target Project, create a text with the words you want to test for synthesis. For example, a paradigm, or some canonical sentence frames.
  2. Create a rules file that simply deletes features from any category that has them. The file identity_rules.t1x in the FLExTrans Documentation\Synthesis Self-Test folder is an example of that, set up for the Spanish sample project.
  3. In FLExTools, set the main FLEx Project to the Target Project. (Remember to change this back, when you go back to working with two projects.)
  4. In FLExTrans, use the Settings Tool to do the following:
    1. Verify the Target Project is set.
    2. Set the Transfer Rules File to identity_rules.t1x. (Remember to change this when you go back to working with two projects.)
    3. Choose the text you want to work on.
  5. In FLExTrans, in the All Steps collection, use Run All to process the text and insert the result into the Target FLEx Project.
    1. It will go into a text with the same name, with (Copy) appended.
    2. Compare this output with your original text.
    3. Any differences you see reflect what would happen if you used this in a transfer process with a different source language, and they probably need to be fixed.
  6. You can try this method with the Spanish sample project in FLExTrans Documentation\Synthesis Self-Test.

6.3.6 What do I do to use my HermitCrab parsing model in synthesis?

By default FLExTrans assumes you will use the XAmple parsing model for synthesizing target morphemes into surface forms. If your target project uses the HermitCrab parsing model, you can make some changes in your FLExTrans setup to use HermitCrab for synthesis. For more details on the HermitCrab parser, see Black, (2014).

To set up FLExTrans for HermitCrab parsing, you need to do two things:

  1. Turn on the setting to enable HermitCrab for synthesis.
    1. Launch the Settings Tool by selecting FLExTrans > Settings from the FLExTools menu.
    2. Click Yes for Use HermitCrab synthesis as shown in (85).
      (85)
  2. Replace the Synthesize Text with STAMP module with the Synthesize Text with HermitCrab module. Here are the steps to do that:
    1. Click on the button which will bring up a list of collections as shown in (86) repeated from (5) above.
      (86)
    2. Click on All Steps.
    3. Then click on Synthesize Text with STAMP module as shown in (87).
      (87)
    4. Now click the button to remove the module from the All Steps collection.
    5. In the lower pane, click on the Synthesize Text with HermitCrab module. As shown in (88).
      (88)
    6. Click the button and then in the upper right pane, click on the FLExTrans.Synthesize Text with HermitCrab module as shown in (89).
      (89)
    7. Now click the button.
    8. The Synthesize Text with HermitCrab module is now in the All Steps collection at the right place as shown in (90).
      (90)
    9. Close the Collection Manager window. Now you can run all the All Steps modules which will include HermitCrab synthesis.

7 Reference documents

The first version of FLExTrans was produced as part of a Master’s Thesis see Lockwood (2015). In 2018 and 2021 Ron presented papers about FLExTrans at the respective BT Conferences. See Lockwood (2018) and Lockwood (2021a). Also in 2021 Ron presented on Syntactic Parsing as a front-end to FLExTrans. See Lockwood (2021b).

A. Appendix

A.1 Starting FLExTools

Here are the steps:

  1. Navigate to the installation folder (typically Documents\FLExTrans\WorkProjects\[YourProject]).
  2. Double-click on the file FlexTools.vbs (a Visual Basic script file).
  3. The FLExTools window should appear which will look something like (2).

A.2 Data Stream Format

The Apertium data stream format consists of one or more lexical units. In FLExTrans, a lexical unit looks something like this:

take1.1 v 3sg[12], [13]

Where take1[14] is the headword from FLEx. The 1.1 subscript means homograph one, sense one. The grammatical category is colored in blue and all other tags are colored in green.

Endnotes

[1]

FLExTools is a general purpose program for running python scripts against a FLEx database.

[2]

You may choose different names for the custom fields, but you also have to update the FLExTrans settings to match these names. The names Target Equivalent and Target Sense Number are already set in the settings that get installed with FLExTrans.

[3]

The text will be taken from the Target Output Synthesis File as defined in the Settings Tool. This is the file created by the Extract Target Lexicon module.

[4]

For this tutorial I am basically reproducing the Apertium article A long introduction to transfer rules. I am mainly modifying it to show the XMLmind XML Editor method of editing the transfer rules, but also the FLExTrans process is assumed instead of the Apertium process.

[5]

The 1 in .t1x stands for the first structural transfer pass. This is the only file we worry about when doing a shallow-transfer system. For advanced-transfer, you use three rule files, and the extensions .t2x and .t3x are also used.

[6]

You would see this if you use the View Source/Target Apertium File Tool. It is the friendly view of the file source_text.txt in the project folder. The actual content looks like this: ^Otići1.1<v><pfv><ptcp_f_sg>$ ^biti1.1<cop><prs><sg><2>$ ^tiho1.1<adv>$ ^i1.1<coordconn>$ ^bez1.1<prep>$ ^pozdrav1.1<n><gen_sg>$
[7]

You would see this if you use the View Source/Target Apertium File Tool and click the Target button. It is the friendly view of the file target_text.txt in the project folder. The actual content looks like this: ^Leave1.1<v><pfv><ptcp_f_sg>$ ^be1.1<cop><prs><sg><2>$ ^quietly1.1<adv>$ ^and1.1<coordconn>$ ^without1.1<prep>$ ^word1.1<n><gen_sg>$
[8]

pst corresponds to the past suffix in the English FLEx project (and also the past tense feature).

[9]

It can be arduous to type in all the grammatical categories that you need for your transfer rules. That’s why there is the FLExTrans tool called Set Up Transfer Rule Grammatical Categories. This tool will insert all possible source and target categories for the a_gram_cat attribute. See section 3.6 for more details.

[10]

In our target_text.txt file it puts a ^ and $ before and after the contents contained within it.

[11]

In our target_text.txt file each tag starts with a <, ends with a >.
[12]

You can use the View Source/Target Apertium File Tool for a more friendly view of the data stream format found in the files source_text.txt and target_text.txt.

[13]

In the plain format the stream format can be explained as follows:
[14]

Technically FLEx only displays a subscript 1 if there is a homograph that exists with subscript 2. Without any homograph the FLEx headword is just plain -- without any subscript.
